sub_topic: Population growth models using differential equations
message_1: A population of rabbits is known to grow continuously at a rate of 5.5% per year. If there are initially 200 rabbits, find the size of the rabbit population after 5 years. Assume that there is no predation or other limiting factors affecting the population growth. Use the exponential growth model to solve the problem.
message_2:
To solve this problem, we will use the exponential growth model formula:

P(t) = P0 * (1 + r)^t

where:
P(t) = the population size after t years
P0 = the initial population size (200 rabbits)
r = the growth rate (5.5% per year, or 0.055 as a decimal)
t = the number of years (5 years)

Plugging the values into the formula, we get:

P(5) = 200 * (1 + 0.055)^5

P(5) = 200 * (1.055)^5

P(5) ≈ 200 * 1.297

P(5) ≈ 259.4

Since we cannot have a fraction of a rabbit, we can round up to the nearest whole number. Therefore, the rabbit population after 5 years will be approximately 260 rabbits.
